stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on restructuring the level design and flow of Course 12, a mine-themed area. He focused on adding new platforming paths, implementing visual details like lighting from fireplaces, and troubleshooting technical issues, while discussing his broader game design philosophies with the chat.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a clever, low-tech optimization trick by naming large geometry alphabetically (e.g., 'ah') to control the engine's render order and improve performance through Z-sorting.
development_findings.quote: I have it named that way because the export order of the meshes is by alphabet so if I name it that way I can guarantee it will be rendered first... you want to Z sort your geometry.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using a private, in-development emulator called 'Project 64 Legacy' which uses the UI from version 1.6 but has a more accurate, modern emulation core that fixes crashes and audio issues.
Kaze is actively reworking Course 12 to improve level flow, focusing on eliminating dead ends and adding interconnected pathways to avoid forced backtracking.
development_findings.quote: The one issue I have in this area, I think, is that from here, the only way you can go is back here, where you came from. And I don't like that.

development_findings.summary: A new gameplay sequence is planned for Course 12 involving a 'Wild West' style shootout with the character Boshi, complete with a countdown and quick-draw mechanic.
Kaze provides direct, blunt feedback on a code contribution from fellow developer Lilaa, indicating an informal and frank collaborative environment.
development_findings.quote: The thing you wrote made the bug happen, where if you walk into a ceiling, you just clip into the ground. So I can't use that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze accepted a technical suggestion from a viewer to optimize collision detection by converting linked lists into arrays on level boot, showing he is open to community input.
development_findings.quote: You know what I'll note that... make coalition into a race.

development_findings.summary: Bosses in the game are being designed to be 'freeform,' allowing players to damage them at almost any time and accelerate invulnerability phases through skillful play.
The mine area of Course 12 will feature rideable minecarts that players can use to build momentum for platforming challenges.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is designing the game for a hardcore, veteran audience, contrasting his approach with Nintendo's mass-market strategy.
context_findings.quote: For like, a weird nerd that's been playing Nintendo games in his basement for 25 years, my game is definitely going to be way better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes novel gameplay concepts over polish, which influenced his mixed feelings about mainstream titles like Mario Odyssey.
context_findings.quote: What I look for in games is like new concepts, new ideas... Mario Odyssey kind of felt like a very polished experience but a lot of the stuff that is to experience barely felt worth experiencing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong dislike for boss battles that involve waiting for an opportunity to attack, preferring the immediate, set-piece style of the original Mario 64 bosses.
context_findings.quote: Boss fights are usually my least favorite part of any game... It's actually one of the reasons I think Mario 64 bosses are some of the best... because they at least don't make you wait.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes a personal trait of pursuing goals with intense immediacy, which he applies to his diet and fitness, sometimes to his own detriment.
context_findings.quote: I also have too much ego so I don't lower the weight while I'm dieting... I set a goal and I want to reach all my goals immediately.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the emulator community for repeatedly suggesting tools that are not suitable for his specific development needs.
context_findings.quote: I am a little bit on edge about people recommending me emulators. Because people recommend me the same free emulators over and over that don't fucking work for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes lives are a "stupid mechanic" for a game like Mario 64 and has implemented "bootless" stars that don't kick the player out of the level.

biobak.summary: Kaze indicates that Biobak performs a major visual overhaul on levels after the initial design is complete, significantly improving their quality.
biobak.quote: The Biobak rework is going to make the force instantly much better.

biobak.summary: Biobak appears to have significant creative autonomy, with the ability to replace Kaze's placeholder assets entirely during the final art pass.
biobak.quote: There's also a good chance that during the reworking, Biobak is just gonna remove this and put his own thing.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina have a playful, teasing dynamic, as shown when they argue about their respective skills in Wii Sports bowling.
zeina.quote: I will absolutely destroy you in bowling Zeina.

key_stories.title: Optimizing with Alphabetical Order
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a clever, low-tech optimization method by renaming a large piece of geometry to 'ah'. This exploited the engine's alphabetical export order to force the object to render first, improving performance through Z-sorting without any complex code.
key_stories.challenge: A key piece of level geometry needed to be rendered first to optimize performance on the N64, but the engine lacked a simple tool to prioritize it.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that the game's engine exports 3D models in alphabetical order. He leveraged this knowledge by renaming the critical mesh with a name that would always be first alphabetically.
key_stories.outcome: By naming the mesh 'ah', Kaze forced it to the top of the alphabetical export list, ensuring it rendered first. This is a clever, practical hack that solves a technical problem by exploiting a simple engine quirk.
key_stories.key_quote: I have it named that way because the export order of the meshes is by alphabet so if I name it that way I can guarantee it will be rendered first on the level.

key_stories.title: Reworking Course 12's Level Flow
key_stories.summary: After identifying a major flaw in the level design for Course 12, Kaze began a significant rework to improve its flow. He is focused on eliminating dead ends and adding new paths to create a more engaging and less linear player experience, reflecting his core design principles.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt that Course 12 was 'not very good' and had poor level flow, specifically a dead-end that forced players to backtrack.
key_stories.process: Kaze performed a 'big restructure' of the level, removing an entire section and moving the train station. He is now iteratively adding new geometry and gameplay elements to connect previously separate areas.
key_stories.outcome: The level is currently being redesigned. Kaze is adding new paths, such as a bridge and a minecart track, to create more options for the player and a more interconnected, free-flowing experience.
key_stories.key_quote: The one issue I have in this area, I think, is that from here, the only way you can go is back here, where you came from. And I don't like that.

key_stories.title: Designing the 'No-Wait' Boss
key_stories.summary: Based on his strong opinions about boss design, Kaze is creating 'freeform' bosses for his game. This design philosophy aims to eliminate the common trope of waiting for an opening, instead allowing players to shorten invulnerability phases through skillful play, ensuring constant engagement.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze dislikes boss fights in most games because they often force the player to wait for openings, which he finds boring.
key_stories.process: Drawing from his negative experiences with bosses in other games and positive experience with Mario 64's bosses, Kaze established a core design principle for his own. He is designing encounters that prioritize continuous player agency over scripted waiting periods.
key_stories.outcome: The bosses in 'Return to Yoshi's Island' are being designed to be 'freeform,' where players can almost always deal damage. Any invulnerability phases can be shortened by skillful play, eliminating the 'waiting game' aspect Kaze dislikes.
key_stories.key_quote: Those phases will be able to be accelerated by just playing well. So you never have that situation where you just kind of stand around awkwardly and wait.
